plottables.py

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 """Prototype plottable object support.
00002 
00003 The main point of this prototype is to provide a clean separation between
00004 the style (plotter details: color, grids, widgets, etc.) and substance
00005 (application details: which information to plot).  Programmers should not be
00006 dictating line colours and plotting symbols.
00007 
00008 Unlike the problem of style in CSS or Word, where most paragraphs look
00009 the same, each line on a graph has to be distinguishable from its neighbours.
00010 Our solution is to provide parametric styles, in which a number of
00011 different classes of object (e.g., reflectometry data, reflectometry
00012 theory) representing multiple graph primitives cycle through a colour
00013 palette provided by the underlying plotter.
00014 
00015 A full treatment would provide perceptual dimensions of prominence and
00016 distinctiveness rather than a simple colour number.
00017 """
00018 
00019 # Design question: who owns the color?
00020 # Is it a property of the plottable?
00021 # Or of the plottable as it exists on the graph?
00022 # Or if the graph?
00023 # If a plottable can appear on multiple graphs, in some case the
00024 # color should be the same on each graph in which it appears, and
00025 # in other cases (where multiple plottables from different graphs
00026 # coexist), the color should be assigned by the graph.  In any case
00027 # once a plottable is placed on the graph its color should not
00028 # depend on the other plottables on the graph.  Furthermore, if
00029 # a plottable is added and removed from a graph and added again,
00030 # it may be nice, but not necessary, to have the color persist.
00031 #
00032 # The safest approach seems to be to give ownership of color
00033 # to the graph, which will allocate the colors along with the
00034 # plottable.  The plottable will need to return the number of
00035 # colors that are needed.
00036 #
00037 # The situation is less clear for symbols.  It is less clear
00038 # how much the application requires that symbols be unique across
00039 # all plots on the graph.
00040 
00041 # Support for ancient python versions
00042 if 'any' not in dir(__builtins__):
00043     def any(L):
00044         for cond in L:
00045             if cond: return True
00046         return False
00047     def all(L):
00048         for cond in L:
00049             if not cond: return False
00050         return True
00051 
00052 # Graph structure for holding multiple plottables
00053 class Graph:
00054     """
00055     Generic plottables graph structure.
00056     
00057     Plot styles are based on color/symbol lists.  The user gets to select
00058     the list of colors/symbols/sizes to choose from, not the application
00059     developer.  The programmer only gets to add/remove lines from the
00060     plot and move to the next symbol/color.
00061 
00062     Another dimension is prominence, which refers to line sizes/point sizes.
00063 
00064     Axis transformations allow the user to select the coordinate view
00065     which provides clarity to the data.  There is no way we can provide
00066     every possible transformation for every application generically, so
00067     the plottable objects themselves will need to provide the transformations.
00068     Here are some examples from reflectometry:
00069        independent: x -> f(x)
00070           monitor scaling: y -> M*y
00071           log:  y -> log(y if y > min else min)
00072           cos:  y -> cos(y*pi/180)
00073        dependent:   x -> f(x,y)
00074           Q4:      y -> y*x^4
00075           fresnel: y -> y*fresnel(x)
00076        coordinated: x,y = f(x,y)
00077           Q:    x -> 2*pi/L (cos(x*pi/180) - cos(y*pi/180))
00078                 y -> 2*pi/L (sin(x*pi/180) + sin(y*pi/180))
00079        reducing: x,y = f(x1,x2,y1,y2)
00080           spin asymmetry: x -> x1, y -> (y1 - y2)/(y1 + y2)
00081           vector net: x -> x1, y -> y1*cos(y2*pi/180)
00082     Multiple transformations are possible, such as Q4 spin asymmetry
00083 
00084     Axes have further complications in that the units of what are being
00085     plotted should correspond to the units on the axes.  Plotting multiple
00086     types on the same graph should be handled gracefully, e.g., by creating
00087     a separate tab for each available axis type, breaking into subplots,
00088     showing multiple axes on the same plot, or generating inset plots.
00089     Ultimately the decision should be left to the user.
00090 
00091     Graph properties such as grids/crosshairs should be under user control,
00092     as should the sizes of items such as axis fonts, etc.  No direct
00093     access will be provided to the application.
00094 
00095     Axis limits are mostly under user control.  If the user has zoomed or
00096     panned then those limits are preserved even if new data is plotted.
00097     The exception is when, e.g., scanning through a set of related lines
00098     in which the user may want to fix the limits so that user can compare
00099     the values directly.  Another exception is when creating multiple
00100     graphs sharing the same limits, though this case may be important
00101     enough that it is handled by the graph widget itself.  Axis limits
00102     will of course have to understand the effects of axis transformations.
00103 
00104     High level plottable objects may be composed of low level primitives.
00105     Operations such as legend/hide/show copy/paste, etc. need to operate
00106     on these primitives as a group.  E.g., allowing the user to have a
00107     working canvas where they can drag lines they want to save and annotate
00108     them.
00109 
00110     Graphs need to be printable.  A page layout program for entire plots
00111     would be nice.
00112     """
00113     def xaxis(self,name,units):
00114         """Properties of the x axis.
00115         """
00116         if self.propprop["xunit"] and units != self.propprop["xunit"]:
00117             print "Plottable: how do we handle non-commensurate units"
00118         self.propprop["xlabel"] = "%s (%s)"%(name,units)
00119         self.propprop["xunit"] = units
00120 
00121     def yaxis(self,name,units):
00122         """Properties of the y axis.
00123         """
00124         if self.propprop["xunit"] and units != self.propprop["xunit"]:
00125             print "Plottable: how do we handle non-commensurate units"
00126         self.propprop["ylabel"] = "%s (%s)"%(name,units)
00127         self.propprop["xunit"] = units
00128         
00129     def title(self,name):
00130         """Graph title
00131         """
00132         self.propprop["title"] = name
00133         
00134     def get(self,key):
00135         """Get the graph properties"""
00136         if key=="color":
00137             return self.colorcolor
00138         elif key == "symbol":
00139             return self.symbolsymbol
00140         else:
00141             return self.propprop[key]
00142 
00143     def set(self,**kw):
00144         """Set the graph properties"""
00145         for key in kw:
00146             if key == "color":
00147                 self.colorcolor = kw[key]%len(self.colorlistcolorlist)
00148             elif key == "symbol":
00149                 self.symbolsymbol = kw[key]%len(self.symbollistsymbollist)
00150             else:
00151                 self.propprop[key] = kw[key]
00152 
00153     def add(self,plottable):
00154         """Add a new plottable to the graph"""
00155         # record the colour associated with the plottable
00156         #TODO: this is not the most intuitive way to keep track of a rotating color
00157         # scheme.  perhaps a function that rotates everytime is is called would be better
00158         self.plottablesplottables[plottable]=self.colorcolor
00159         self.colorcolor += plottable.colors()
00160         
00161     def changed(self):
00162         """Detect if any graphed plottables have changed"""
00163         return any([p.changed() for p in self.plottablesplottables])
00164 
00165     def delete(self,plottable):
00166         """Remove an existing plottable from the graph"""
00167         if plottable in self.plottablesplottables:
00168             del self.plottablesplottables[plottable]
00169 
00170     def reset(self):
00171         """Reset the graph."""
00172         self.colorcolor = 0
00173         self.symbolsymbol = 0
00174         self.propprop = {"xlabel":"", "xunit":None,
00175                      "ylabel":"","yunit":None,
00176                      "title":""}
00177         self.plottablesplottables = {}
00178 
00179     def _make_labels(self):
00180         # Find groups of related plottables
00181         sets = {}
00182         for p in self.plottablesplottables:
00183             if p.__class__ in sets:
00184                 sets[p.__class__].append(p)
00185             else:
00186                 sets[p.__class__] = [p]
00187                 
00188         # Ask each plottable class for a set of unique labels
00189         labels = {}
00190         for c in sets:
00191             labels.update(c.labels(sets[c]))
00192         
00193         return labels
00194 
00195     def render(self,plot):
00196         """Redraw the graph"""
00197         plot.clear()
00198         plot.properties(self.propprop)
00199         labels = self._make_labels_make_labels()
00200         for p in self.plottablesplottables:
00201             p.render(plot,color=self.plottablesplottables[p],symbol=0,label=labels[p])
00202         plot.render()
00203 
00204     def __init__(self,**kw):
00205         self.resetreset()
00206         self.setset(**kw)
00207         #self.colorlist = ['b','g','r','c','m','y']
00208         #self.symbollist = ['o','x','^','v','<','>','+','s','d','D','h','H','p']

00211 # Transform interface definition
00212 # No need to inherit from this class, just need to provide
00213 # the same methods.
00214 class Transform:
00215     """Define a transform plugin to the plottable architecture.
00216     
00217     Transforms operate on axes.  The plottable defines the
00218     set of transforms available for it, and the axes on which
00219     they operate.  These transforms can operate on the x axis
00220     only, the y axis only or on the x and y axes together.
00221     
00222     This infrastructure is not able to support transformations
00223     such as log and polar plots as these require full control
00224     over the drawing of axes and grids.
00225     
00226     A transform has a number of attributes.
00227     
00228     name: user visible name for the transform.  This will
00229         appear in the context menu for the axis and the transform
00230         menu for the graph.
00231     type: operational axis.  This determines whether the 
00232         transform should appear on x,y or z axis context
00233         menus, or if it should appear in the context menu for
00234         the graph.
00235     inventory: (not implemented) 
00236         a dictionary of user settable parameter names and
00237         their associated types.  These should appear as keyword 
00238         arguments to the transform call.  For example, Fresnel 
00239         reflectivity requires the substrate density:
00240              { 'rho': type.Value(10e-6/units.angstrom**2) }
00241         Supply reasonable defaults in the callback so that 
00242         limited plotting clients work even though they cannot 
00243         set the inventory.
00244     """
00245         
00246     def __call__(self,plottable,**kwargs):
00247         """Transform the data.  Whenever a plottable is added
00248         to the axes, the infrastructure will apply all required
00249         transforms.  When the user selects a different representation
00250         for the axes (via menu, script, or context menu), all
00251         plottables on the axes will be transformed.  The
00252         plottable should store the underlying data but set
00253         the standard x,dx,y,dy,z,dz attributes appropriately.
00254         
00255         If the call raises a NotImplemented error the dataline 
00256         will not be plotted.  The associated string will usually
00257         be 'Not a valid transform', though other strings are possible.
00258         The application may or may not display the message to the
00259         user, along with an indication of which plottable was at fault.
00260         """
00261         raise NotImplemented,"Not a valid transform"
00262 
00263     # Related issues
00264     # ==============
00265     #
00266     # log scale:
00267     #    All axes have implicit log/linear scaling options.
00268     # 
00269     # normalization:
00270     #    Want to display raw counts vs detector efficiency correction
00271     #    Want to normalize by time/monitor/proton current/intensity.
00272     #    Want to display by eg. counts per 3 sec or counts per 10000 monitor.
00273     #    Want to divide by footprint (ab initio, fitted or measured).
00274     #    Want to scale by attenuator values.
00275     #
00276     # compare/contrast:
00277     #    Want to average all visible lines with the same tag, and
00278     #    display difference from one particular line.  Not a transform
00279     #    issue?
00280     #
00281     # multiline graph:
00282     #    How do we show/hide data parts.  E.g., data or theory, or 
00283     #    different polarization cross sections?  One way is with
00284     #    tags: each plottable has a set of tags and the tags are
00285     #    listed as check boxes above the plotting area.  Click a
00286     #    tag and all plottables with that tag are hidden on the
00287     #    plot and on the legend.
00288     #
00289     # nonconformant y-axes:
00290     #    What do we do with temperature vs. Q and reflectivity vs. Q
00291     #    on the same graph?
00292     #
00293     # 2D -> 1D:
00294     #    Want various slices through the data.  Do transforms apply
00295     #    to the sliced data as well?
00296 
00297 
00298 class Plottable:
00299     def xaxis(self, name, units):
00300         self._xaxis_xaxis = name
00301         self._xunit_xunit = units
00302 
00303     def yaxis(self, name, units):
00304         self._yaxis_yaxis = name
00305         self._yunit_yunit = units
00306 
00307     @classmethod
00308     def labels(cls,collection):
00309         """
00310         Construct a set of unique labels for a collection of plottables of 
00311         the same type.
00312         
00313         Returns a map from plottable to name.
00314         """
00315         n = len(collection)
00316         map = {}
00317         if n > 0:
00318             basename = str(cls).split('.')[-1]
00319             if n == 1:
00320                 map[collection[0]] = basename
00321             else:
00322                 for i in xrange(len(collection)):
00323                     map[collection[i]] = "%s %d"%(basename,i)
00324         return map
00325     ##Use the following if @classmethod doesn't work
00326     # labels = classmethod(labels)
00327 
00328     def __init__(self):
00329         self.lineWidthlineWidth=0.5
00330         self.lineStylelineStyle='-'
00331     
00332     def render(self,plot):
00333         """The base class makes sure the correct units are being used for
00334         subsequent plottable.  
00335         
00336         For now it is assumed that the graphs are commensurate, and if you 
00337         put a Qx object on a Temperature graph then you had better hope 
00338         that it makes sense.
00339         """
00340         plot.xaxis(self._xaxis_xaxis, self._xunit_xunit)
00341         plot.yaxis(self._yaxis_yaxis, self._yunit_yunit)
00342         
00343     def colors(self):
00344         """Return the number of colors needed to render the object"""
00345         return 1
00346

00348 class Data1D(Plottable):
00349     """Data plottable: scatter plot of x,y with errors in x and y.
00350     """
00351     
00352     def __init__(self,x,y,dx=None,dy=None):
00353         """Draw points specified by x[i],y[i] in the current color/symbol.
00354         Uncertainty in x is given by dx[i], or by (xlo[i],xhi[i]) if the
00355         uncertainty is asymmetric.  Similarly for y uncertainty.
00356 
00357         The title appears on the legend.
00358         The label, if it is different, appears on the status bar.
00359         """
00360         self.xx = x
00361         self.yy = y
00362         self.dxdx = dx
00363         self.dydy = dy
00364 
00365     def render(self,plot,**kw):
00366         Plottable.render(self,plot)
00367         plot.points(self.xx,self.yy,dx=self.dxdx,dy=self.dydy,**kw)
00368 
00369     def changed(self):
00370         return False
00371 
00372     
00373 class Theory1D(Plottable):
00374     """Theory plottable: line plot of x,y with confidence interval y.
00375     """
00376     def __init__(self,x,y,dy=None):
00377         """Draw lines specified in x[i],y[i] in the current color/symbol.
00378         Confidence intervals in x are given by dx[i] or by (xlo[i],xhi[i])
00379         if the limits are asymmetric.
00380         
00381         The title is the name that will show up on the legend.
00382         """
00383         self.xx = x
00384         self.yy = y
00385  
00386         self.dydy = dy
00387 
00388     def render(self,plot,**kw):
00389         plot.curve(self.xx,self.yy,dy=self.dydy,**kw)
00390 
00391     def changed(self):
00392         return False

00396 class Fit1D(Plottable):
00397     """Fit plottable: composed of a data line plus a theory line.  This
00398     is treated like a single object from the perspective of the graph,
00399     except that it will have two legend entries, one for the data and
00400     one for the theory.
00401 
00402     The color of the data and theory will be shared."""
00403 
00404     def __init__(self,data=None,theory=None):
00405         self.datadata=data
00406         self.theorytheory=theory
00407 
00408     def render(self,plot,**kw):
00409         self.datadata.render(plot,**kw)
00410         self.theorytheory.render(plot,**kw)
00411 
00412     def changed(self):
00413         return self.datadata.changed() or self.theorytheory.changed()

00417 def sample_graph():
00418     import numpy as nx
00419     
00420     # Construct a simple graph
00421     if False:
00422         x = nx.array([1,2,3,4,5,6],'d')
00423         y = nx.array([4,5,6,5,4,5],'d')
00424         dy = nx.array([0.2, 0.3, 0.1, 0.2, 0.9, 0.3])
00425     else:
00426         x = nx.linspace(0,1.,10000)
00427         y = nx.sin(2*nx.pi*x*2.8)
00428         dy = nx.sqrt(100*nx.abs(y))/100
00429     data = Data1D(x,y,dy=dy)
00430     data.xaxis('distance', 'm')
00431     data.yaxis('time', 's')
00432     graph = Graph()
00433     graph.title('Walking Results')
00434     graph.add(data)
00435     graph.add(Theory1D(x,y,dy=dy))
00436 
00437     return graph

00439 def demo_plotter(graph):
00440     import wx
00441     #from pylab_plottables import Plotter
00442     from mplwxplotter import Plotter
00443 
00444     # Make a frame to show it
00445     app = wx.PySimpleApp()
00446     frame = wx.Frame(None,-1,'Plottables')
00447     plotter = Plotter(frame)
00448     frame.Show()
00449 
00450     # render the graph to the pylab plotter
00451     graph.render(plotter)
00452     
00453     class GraphUpdate:
00454         callnum=0
00455         def __init__(self,graph,plotter):
00456             self.graph,self.plotter = graph,plotter
00457         def __call__(self):
00458             if self.graph.changed(): 
00459                 self.graph.render(self.plotter)
00460                 return True
00461             return False
00462         def onIdle(self,event):
00463             #print "On Idle checker %d"%(self.callnum)
00464             self.callnum = self.callnum+1
00465             if self.__call__(): 
00466                 pass # event.RequestMore()
00467     update = GraphUpdate(graph,plotter)
00468     frame.Bind(wx.EVT_IDLE, update.onIdle)
00469     app.MainLoop()

00471 import sys; print sys.version
00472 if __name__ == "__main__":
00473     demo_plotter(sample_graph())
